fields.description:
Hi All,

Setup of Eucalyptus 3.1 with following details

{code}
Machine 1:  CLC/W/CC/SC
Machine 2:  CLC/W/CC
Machine 3:  NC
{code}

CLC/Walrus/Cluster-Controller are setup in HA.

After a successful CC failover, the traffic is still broken. The reason is lack of ARP announcement from new enabled CC.

After CC failover from A to B, the public IPs and private subnets gateway IPs are bonded and up on new enabled CC-B. But there's no ARP announcement (AKA Gratuitous ARP) sent out from CC-B, so the surrounding hosts and routers still use old IP<->MAC mapping which leads traffic to still go to CC-A. 

This will be fixed until next ARP request sent from surrounding hosts and routers after current ARP entries time out. Some network devices like Cisco Router takes up to 4 hours(default ARP timeout value) to age ARP entries, which causes long time network break to the cloud.


Test steps:
0. 
Constantly ping an instance public IP from a host outside the cloud, take 10.68.93.100 as example

{code}
H:\>ping 10.68.93.100 -t
 Pinging 10.68.93.100 with 32 bytes of data:
Reply from 10.68.93.100: bytes=32 time=2ms TTL=59
Reply from 10.68.93.100: bytes=32 time=1ms TTL=59
Reply from 10.68.93.100: bytes=32 time=2ms TTL=59
{code}

1. 
On enabled CC Euca3-FE-2 , check public address. (10.68.93.100 as example)

{code}
[root@Euca3-FE-2 ~]# ip addr show
1: eth0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP
qlen 1000
link/ether 00:1e:0b:4a:6c:2e brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
inet 169.254.169.254/32 scope link eth0
inet 10.68.93.7/24 brd 10.68.93.255 scope global eth0
inet 192.168.79.129/26 brd 192.168.79.191 scope global eth0
inet 10.68.93.100/32 scope global eth0
inet 10.68.93.101/32 scope global eth0
{code}

2. 
On Router, check current ARP entry for IP 10.68.93.100

{code}
VaaS_1.0_CoreSW_3750#sh arp | inc 10.68.93.100
Protocol Address Age (min) Hardware Addr Type Interface
 Internet 10.68.93.100  161 001e.0b4a.6c2e ARPA Vlan931
{code}

We can see on Router, 10.68.93.100 is mapped with enabled CC Euca3-FE-2 eth0 MAC: 001e.0b4a.6c2e

3. 
Shutdown current enabled CC node Euca3-FE-2, wait for CC to fail over to another host Euca3-FE-1.

4. 
On new enabled CC node Euca3-FE-1, check Euca public address:

{code}
[root@Euca3-FE-1 ~]# ip addr show
1: eth0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP
qlen 1000
link/ether 00:1e:0b:60:eb:9a brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
inet 169.254.169.254/32 scope link eth0
inet 10.68.93.6/24 brd 10.68.93.255 scope global eth0
inet 192.168.79.129/26 brd 192.168.79.191 scope global eth0
inet 10.68.93.100/32 scope global eth0
inet 10.68.93.101/32 scope global eth0
{code}

Now  public IP 10.68.93.100 is bonded and up on Euca3-FE-1 host.

5.
On Router, check again current ARP entry for IP 10.68.93.100

{code}
VaaS_1.0_CoreSW_3750#sh arp | inc 10.68.93.100
Protocol Address Age (min) Hardware Addr Type Interface
Internet 10.68.93.100  168 001e.0b4a.6c2e ARPA Vlan931
{code}

10.68.93.100 is still mapped to old MAC before failover, no update happens.

6. 
Check ping result, ping starts to fail when shut down the enabled CC node.

{code}
Reply from 10.68.93.100: bytes=32 time=1ms TTL=59
Reply from 10.68.93.100: bytes=32 time=2ms TTL=59
Request timed out. 
Request timed out.
Request timed out.
{code}

7.
(Workround) Manually to send a Gratuitous ARP Broadcast on new enabled CC node Euca3-FE-1, can update ARP tables of devices in the network.

{code}
[root@Euca3-FE-1 ~]# arping -U -I eth0 -c 1 10.68.93.100
ARPING 10.68.93.100 from 10.68.93.100 eth0
Sent 1 probes (1 broadcast(s))
Received 0 response(s)
{code}

Check ARP entry on Router, IP<->MAC mapping has been updated:

{code}
VaaS1.0_CoreSW_3750#sh arp | inc 10.68.93.100
Internet 10.68.93.100 0  001e.0b60.eb9a ARPA Vlan931
{code}

Check ping result, ping works again:
 
{code}
Request timed out.
Request timed out.
Reply from 10.68.93.100: bytes=32 time=1ms TTL=59
Reply from 10.68.93.100: bytes=32 time=1ms TTL=59
Reply from 10.68.93.100: bytes=32 time=1ms TTL=59
{code}

Conclusion:

This should be a bug of Eucalyptus 3 HA, when a DISABLED CC takes over and becomes ENABLED, it should send Gratuitous ARP broadcast to announce the IP<->MAC mapping changes.
fields.summary: new enabled CC in HA does not do ARP announcement after a failure

comments.body: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/DOC-170
Moving to a feature request
Just discussed this with Dan, and I'm starting research to determine how to best accomplish this.
scoping version is 3.1.3 , does that exists? can we get priority in this bug and possible release this is scheduled for?
This is a new feature request.  We attempted to get this into 3.2, but the current feature set we committed to caused this to get bumped out (it was best effort).

Is there a logical entry point in CC that is aware of the state 
transition  ( failover) that can issue the arping -U  update ?

John, I would think the CC would need to query the CLC in some manner to determine its status.  Chris may be a better one to ping on this as to what could be done to inform the CC to send the ARP update.

For https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-2412 I used the CCclient_full compiled from the Eucalyptus source to query the CC state, this as a basis for priority/voting in keepalived based VIP cluster.

We could also use CCclient_full to do something similar for the CC failover and arp, we'd need to query the CC state every n seconds and trigger the arp if the state changes. We could also query the CLC for the state info, but I think it's better to keep the state queries local.

This could be a useful workaround til the gratuitous arp is part of a release.

More info here: https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/wiki/Keepalived-VIP-for-Node-Controller-Gateways

I'm looking into how best to integrate the gratuitous arp into the CC to eliminate the need for such a workaround.

(Shhh! Don't tell Tim!)

Just to be clear, when I said this wasn't going to make 3.2, I meant 3.2.0.   We will target this for a 3.2.x maintenance release.  Moved this to a bug to make sure it stays very high on the sustaining/engineering radar.
Also, when this bug is being worked on, let's make sure we can cover EUCA-3540 with the same commit due to their similar nature

Hey all,

What we're likely to add to the code is some logic in the CC that sends unsolicited ARP requests whenever a new 'public' IP gets assigned to a CC interface.  This will cover both the case where a failover occurs, when elastic IPs are assigned across clusters, and in any other scenario where a given IP is used on separate machines.  Interestingly, there is a simple unix command that I believe has already been referenced by someone else that is an easy way to send such an unsolicited arp request:

arping -c 2 -U -I <interface> <local ip address in question>

so, if a machine just got '192.168.253.2' assigned to its 'eth0', then 

arping -c 2 -U -I eth0 192.168.253.2

will broadcast an unsolicited ARP message that should trigger servers and network devices on that broadcast network to update their arp cache entries. 

While engineering works on integration into euca, perhaps we can put together a simple script (cronable) that takes the public IPs listed in eucalyptus.conf, plus the public interface, and loops over the IPs periodically.  If this script is run on the CC periodically, it should keep the ARP caches up to date.  Good news is that the command fails if the IP is not currently assigned to the specified interface, so it should be safe to run independently on two separate HA CCs (it will periodically send the unsolicited ARP requests on the CC where the IPs are assigned, and the commands will just fail on the CC that doesn't currently have those public IPs assigned).  Thus it should be safe to run in a loop without needing to interrogate anything from eucalyptus other than 'public interface' and 'public ips'.  What do you think?

-D

Thanks Dan, this is great news.

I think a script would be helpful as it would let us not only get a broader test exposure to the new ARP behavior on the CC, it would also allow some users to move forward with their HA setups.  Support can perform a basic set of testing against the script as well as determine what level of support we want to provide for this script.

Sound like a plan?

[~graziano] wrote something for plinga when we found this  https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/SUP-122 , details are in that ticket, we could do something like that on the CCs, by reading the eucalyptus.conf for PUBLICIPS and PUBINTERFACE, finally executing his 1 liner, thoughts?
This would be a patch to add a cron-based script?

well, haven't really talked deeply about it. but I would think that a patch that calls a script when the appropriate events happens would be the path I would think of. Cronjob seems a bit of a hack, and a bit more difficult to setup from packages, although quite a few packages do have indeed cronjob operations. What were you thinking?
I brought up cron based upon Dan's earlier comments. Hadn't necessarily been thinking directly down that path...

[~graziano], I plan to merge Dan's patch, which adds arping calls to the CC code. I considered modifying it to allow for detection (via autoconf?) of the version of arping installed, but the 'arping' package version in Debian/Ubuntu doesn't appear to provide any unsolicited ARP functionality at all. Perhaps we should make a release note that anyone running on Debian/Ubuntu (already an unsupported distro) should be sure to install the iputils-arping package rather than the arping package?

autoconf detection won't do since one could change the package after installation. We could depend on a specific package. I agree on release notes and documentation though, since this will require admin co-operation to get it right.
Document what executable(s) the CC needs and then check for them at runtime, not build time.  Pulling in the appropriate dependencies is the job of the packager.

My thoughts re autoconf were mostly for development-minded folks who are already straying away from our supported environment. But you're right--runtime checks would be preferable over build-time checks.

If only we had a fault subsystem to warn of such things....

Committed [~nurmi]'s fixes to maint/3.2/testing. [~neil] is having an explicit dependency upon the 'arping' utility (part of the 'iputils' package) added.

This dependency should also be documented as a release note, as not all versions of 'arping' support the functionality required by our usage; in particular, the version supplied in Debian's standalone 'arping' package will not work.

Ran an instance on HA POC setup. Verified that instance can be pinged from outside the cloud before fail over and after fail over.
Verified in cc.log that CC is sending unsolicited ARP to flush caches.
